The glycerol value addition by ketalization with acetone leads to solketal. Herein, we demonstrate the comparative efficiency of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, using Hβ-zeolite & sulfated zirconia (SO4 2--ZrO2) as Brønsted and Lewis acid catalysts, respectively, for ketalization of glycerol to solketal. The catalysts were characterized using conventional techniques. Total acidity of both catalysts was ascertained with NH3-TPD. The sulfur content of SO4 2--ZrO2 was determined by CHNS analysis. The Brønsted/Lewis character of total acid sites for both catalysts was determined using FTIR of pyridine-Chemisorbed catalysts. Studies revealed that 5% (w/w) catalyst, 25 °C temperature and 2-hour reaction time were optimum parameters for Hβ-zeolite while, SO4 2--ZrO2 required 50 °C to match the performance. Hβ-zeolite exhibited higher selectivity at lower temperatures towards ketal and reusability without any performance drop upto 10 cycles. The performance-edge vis-à-vis reusability of catalysts indicated tolerance of Lewis acid sites towards hydration, where Hβ-zeolite outperforms SO4 2--ZrO2. Graphical abstract ga1 Keywords Glycerol Solketal Sulfated-zirconia Hβ-zeolite Heterogenous catalysis Solid-acid catalyst Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Valorization of glycerol is one of the most explored research areas in the past few decades due to the abundance of it owing to biodiesel production [1–3]. Out of several pathways and important products, the production of Sol ketal has remained one of the most investigated and practiced processes [4,5]. The evident inclination towards solketal is due to the relative ease of its formation at milder conditions in the presence of acid catalysts [6–8]. The choices and variety of catalysts are numerous and a significant amount of research and development is going on in the development of novel efficient catalysts, in particular the heterogeneous catalysts [9–11]. Over the years the most used and studied heterogeneous solid acid catalyst is zeolite [12]. Proton exchanged β-zeolite, that is Hβ-zeolite is proven to be an excellent catalytic system yielding cleaner reactions with near quantitative yields [12]. One of the main purposes and advantages to opt for solid acid heterogeneous catalysis for this ketal formation reaction is higher yields, milder conditions, and the ease of catalyst removal. In all the reported literature, the efficiency of a heterogeneous acid catalyst depends on two factors: (i) the surface area of the catalyst and (ii) the number of acidic sites on the catalyst surface. Considering the available state of the art, the majority of catalytic systems have either Brønsted acid sites or Lewis acid sites[8,11]or in some cases, the combination of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites both are present on the surfaces and they facilitate the elimination of water for ketal formation [8,12]. probing the role of the nature and potency of the specific acid site for this chosen model reaction of solketal formation would be an important exercise in the direction of enhancing the knowledge base with respect to site specificity in an important reaction and can have implications on many other similar condensation reactions involving dehydration. Sulfated zirconia, Amberlyst, MSA-loaded silica, Phospho-tungstic acid supported on various solid supports are prime examples of Brønsted acid sites dominating catalytic surfaces[10,13]While the other prominent catalytic systems such as β - zeolite, transition metal oxides [8] are either solely Lewis acid sites containing catalysts or offer Lewis-Brønsted mixed acidic sites. All these reported catalysts gave very high yields for solketal formation in just one step with very mild conditions such as stirring for 2–6 h at ambient temperature [25 °C]. However, the other important aspect of using a heterogeneous catalyst system, is the reusability of the catalyst, and that is not exhaustively and thoroughly probed in previous studies with an interest on the role of the catalytic sites in conversion efficiency and reusability. The role of Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites in the reaction under investigation and for similar reactions, as well as the effect of the nature of the acid sites in ensuring or impugning the reusability of such catalysts is of enormous interest. Herein, we have probed the presence of Brønsted/Lewis sites and their tolerance against the water molecules formed during the reaction in order to provide reusability without any extra workup efforts put into catalyst re-activation. One of the main advantages of the heterogeneous catalysts is their reusability with minimal workup in the direction of the restoration of their activity. The biggest hurdle in this is poisoning or deactivation of catalytic sites by the adsorption of reactants, products, or the small molecules which are getting eliminated during the course of the reaction. In the case of the reaction under investigation, solketal formation, water is being eliminated leading to the condensation product. The endurance of acid sites against water molecules would ensure the longevity of such a catalyst without getting de-activated and hence the superior reusability. In this study, the comparison of both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites is performed. The deactivation of the catalytic sites due to released water molecules during the reaction is observed. Binding of this water to the catalyst sites via H-bonding and thereby hampering the deprotonation process is investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Glycerol (≥ 99.5%) was procured from Sigma Aldrich. Acetone (≥ 99%), ammonia solution (≥ 25%), and sulphuric acid (∼ 98%) were procured from Merck. Zirconium oxychloride octahydrate (≥98%)was from Loba Chemie. Sodium form of beta zeolite was made available from Sud Chemie India Pvt Ltd, and ammonium chloride (≥ 99%) was purchased from S.D. fine chem. 2.2 Catalyst preparation In the current study, sulfated zirconia and Hβ-zeolite were used as solid acid catalysts in the production of solketal. These catalysts are denoted as SZ and HBZ, respectively. 2.2.1 Hβ-zeolite (HBZ) Hβ-zeolite, HBZ was prepared from sodium form of beta zeolite by the ion-exchange following the reported procedure [14]. 10 g of sodium beta zeolite was placed in a 250 mL round bottom flask and treated with 100 mL of 1 M of ammonium chloride aqueous solution at 90 °C for 4 h. The Solid was then filtered and washed with hot water until it became chloride-free (checked chloride as AgCl ppts). After ensuring the complete removal of chloride, the ammonium ion replaced beta zeolite was subsequently dried at 100 °C overnight. The dried sample of ammonium exchanged beta zeolite was calcined at 550 °C for 4 h to obtain HBZ. The prepared HBZ was characterized by XRD, XRF, BET surface area-TPD, and FTIR. 2.2.2 Sulfated zirconia, (SZ) As per the reported method the sulfated zirconia (SO4 2--ZrO2), SZ was prepared from Zirconium oxychloride precursor [11]. In which, about 25 g of zirconium oxychloride, was dissolved in doubly distilled water with stirring. To this clear solution, dilute aqueous ammonia was added dropwise with vigorous stirring until the pH of the solution reached 8. The obtained precipitates were washed with distilled water until free from chloride ions and dried at 120 °C for 24 h. The sulfonation of Zirconium hydroxide was imparted on a dried finely ground powder using 1 M H2SO4(30 mL) by stirring for 30 min. Excess water was evaporated on a water bath and the resulting sample was oven-dried at 120 °C for 12 h and calcined at 650 °C for 4 h in an air atmosphere and stored in a vacuum desiccator The prepared SZ catalyst was characterized with XRD, XRF, BET-surface area-TPD, CHNS elemental analysis and FTIR. 2.3 Synthesis of solketal The condensation of glycerol (0.5 g, 0.054 mol) with acetone by using different acetone/ glycerol molar ratios over heterogeneous acid catalyst as either SZ or HBZ, of different % (w/w) ratios was carried out through reflux in a Radleys reaction station under atmosphere. The reaction temperature was controlled with an external thermostat equipped with an external thermocouple of 1.0 °C accuracy immersed in the reaction mixture. The stirring speed was set to 500 rpm in all experiments. The product mixtures were analyzed with a gas chromatograph, equipped with a mass spectrometer detector [Agilent 5975 C GC/MS (EI), Agilent 7890 A GC equipped with a capillary column (30 m x 0.25 mm ID x 0.25 µm film)]. As a carrier gas helium was used with a flow rate of 1.2 mL/min. The oven temperature was adjusted to 300 °C. The experiments were performed in triplicate for conversion data and the selectivity for 5 & 6 membered ring isomers was deduced using area under the curve for their corresponding peaks in the gas chromatograph. The standard deviation was found to be of 0.52% and the average values were reported. Scheme 1. 2.4 Catalyst characterization 2.4.1 X-ray diffraction The X-ray diffraction studies of catalyst samples were performed on a Bruker, Advanced D8, using Cu K radiation (λ = 1.5418) and a Lynx Eye detector, scanning the samples in two ranges of 5–80° at a scanning rate of 0.02° s−1. 2.4.2 FT-IR FTIR spectroscopy of the samples were carried out on an FT-IR spectrophotometer (IRPrestige-21, Shimadzu) using a Diffuse Reflectance Scanning disc technique in the range of 500–4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1 by mixing the sample with dried KBr (in a 1/20 wt. ratio). The type of surface acidity (Brønsted/ Lewis) in the HBZ and SZ catalyst samples was revealed by FTIR analysis of the pyridine adsorbed samples of respective catalysts. The sample (0.2 g) was activated at 2000 C and 4000 C for 2 h. The activated sample was vacuum cooled in a desiccator for 24 h before being exposed to pyridine (10 mL) vapor. The pyridine-adsorbed sample was degassed under a vacuum for 15 min to remove physisorbed pyridine. 2.4.3 Elemental analysis C,H,N,S analysis of the samples were carried out on a CHNS analyzer from Elementar-Unicube Germany. In this process accurately 2 mg Samples were weighed for CHNS in tin boats. Tin boats with samples were packed and pressed properly in a square shape. Sample was inserted into the instrument by means of the autosampler in CHNS mode. The temperature of the combustion furnace was 1150 °C and in the reduction chamber was 850 °C. The standards were used for calibration and the acceptance criteria for calibration was ± 0.3%. 2.4.4 BET and ammonia TPD The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of the samples was measured from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm study at liquid nitrogen temperature (77 K) using a micromeritics surface area analyzer after they were degassed at 110 °C for 2 h under vacuum. temperature programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3 TPD) performed on the samples using Micromeritics, USA, instrument. The samples (50 mg) were preheated for 1 h at 100 °C in helium flow (30 mL h-1). At 50 °C, the NH3 was adsorbed on the samples by exposing them to a flow of helium-mixed NH3gas (10%, 20 mL h-1) for 1 h. The desorption of NH3 was measured using gas chromatography with a thermal conductivity detector after heating the sample to final temperatures of 350 °C and 800 °C (12 °C/min) (TCD). 2.4.5 X-ray fluorescence spectrometry X-ray Fluorescence analysis was carried out on AxiosMAX X-ray Fluorescence Spectrometer from PANalytical-Netherland and the data acquisition was performed with Omnian standard-less software. 2.4.6 Thermal analysis (TGA/DTG) Thermogravimetry was performed using Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC1 equipped with a small furnace (SF) from 25 °C to 700 °C, temperature ramp was 10 °C/min under 50 mL/min Nitrogen flow. The first derivative was obtained using STAR e-software on TGA curve to deduce DTG. 3 Results and discussion The prepared catalysts SZ and HBZ were characterized using XRD, FTIR, and thermal techniques. The results were consistent with the reported data. The XRD pattern ( Fig. 1A) of HBZ shows the characteristic diffraction peaks at 7.8° and 22.4°at 2 theta values for 101 and 302 crystal planes, respectively of HBZ [15]. The Fig. 1(B) shows the XRD pattern of SZ, where peaks at 2θ of 30.20°, 35.29°, 50.26°, and 60.26° correspond to crystal planes 101, 110, 112, and 211 respectively showing the tetragonal crystalline phase of ZrO2 [16]. The sharp band at 3651 cm−1 and the broad peak at 3213 cm−1in FT-IR spectrum of HBZ ( Fig. 2a) are representing free and hydrogen bonded silanols, respectively of zeolite [17]. The peak at 1630 cm−1 is O-H banding of adsorbed water molecules. The characteristic peaks for Si-O-Al, Si-O-Si, Si-O, etc. of zeolite can be seen in the range of 1215 cm−1 to 630 cm−1 [18]. The FT-IR spectrum of SZ (Fig. 2B) showed characteristic IR bands of sulfate SO4 2- in the region of 1200–900 cm−1 [19]. The peaks 1232, 1142, 1065, and 999 cm−1 are assigned to asymmetric and symmetric starching frequency of SO and S-O bond. The intense peak around 1650 cm−1 was attributed to O-H banding of adsorbed water molecules. The broad peak 3203 cm−1 represents OH stretching and the small peak at 3552 cm−1 is assigned to free surface OH groups. The proportionate presence of Si and Al in zeolite structure were determined by XRF, where Si/Al ratio was found to be 24, indicating the moderate presence of Al2O3 with respect to Silica in the zeolite framework. This ratio affects the spatial arrangement of zeolite interiors as well as the abundance and type of acid sites. In the case of SZ, the number of -SO3H groups present, determines the Brønsted acidity. BET surface area and TPD analysis were carried out for both the catalysts to determine the surface area and the number of total acid sites. The BET surface area of HBZ was found to be much higher (550 m2/g) as compared to SZ (72 m2/g). While the pore sizes were 58 Å and 35 Å respectively for HBZ and SZ. Temperature programmed desorption of NH3 gas provided information about total acidic sites on HBZ and SZ catalysts, which were found to be 1.87 and 1.17 (mMol NH3 per gram catalyst) respectively. Table 1 shows that the HBZ has an enormously high surface area compared to SZ, while the acidity is also about 2 times higher than that of SZ. This gives an edge to HBZ for the ketal formation reaction. Moreover, CHNS elemental analysis of freshly prepared SZ showed 11% of Sulfur, corresponding to -SO3H groups, which give rise to Brønsted acidity in SZ. NH3-TPD technique gave the measure of the total acid sites on the catalyst surfaces, however, the Lewis or Brønsted nature of the acid sites of these catalysts was revealed by pyridine adsorption studies. The infra-red spectra of pyridine-chemisorbed samples of the catalysts HBZ and SZ showed the IR peaks corresponding to the pyridine adsorbed on Lewis and Brønsted sites of the catalysts HBZ and SZ. The quantification of the adsorbed pyridine is performed using area under the curve for a particular IR peak corresponding to the pyridine adsorption. This analysis differentiated the nature of acid sites as Brønsted and/or Lewis based on their IR peak positions corresponding to the adsorbed pyridine as shown in Fig. 3(a) and (b) for HBZ and SZ respectively. The FTIR of pyridine-adsorbed HBZ showed three significant peaks between 1400 and 1600 cm−1. The peaks at 1445 cm−1 are associated with Lewis acid sites, while for Brønsted sites at 1547 cm−1. In the case of SZ the FTIR peaks corresponding to pyridine bound to only one type of acidic sites were observed at 1535 cm−1 attributed to only Brønsted acid sites [20]. 3.1 Optimization of catalytic performance with respect to solketal reaction Before employing the catalysts, the activation of catalysts is always recommended in the case of heterogeneous catalytic systems for optimum results. In the reaction under investigation, the removal of water is crucial for the formation of products, and therefore, the pre-activation of a catalyst to get rid of the adsorbed water molecules at the catalytic surface is necessary. In the present study, we have selected two heterogeneous acidic catalysts viz; HBZ and SZ. Activation of the catalyst is crucial for the condensation reactions coupled with the elimination of water. We have optimized the activation temperature for both the catalytic systems with respect to the catalytic conversion of glycerol to solketal (dioxolane) and selectivity for a 5-membered dioxolane vs 6-membered (dioxane) product as shown in Table 2 below. SZ is reported to be activated at 400 °C [21]. Based on the conversion of glycerol and the exclusive selectivity for 5-membered ketal at a 1:2 glycerol to acetone fixed ratio, the HBZ catalyst had performed optimum in the case of activation temperature at 200 °C. On the other hand, the reported optimum activation temperature for SZ was found to be 400 °C [21]. This makes HBZ a preferred choice compared to SZ because of the significantly lower activation temperature required to achieve maximum conversion with respect to the chosen model reaction. The catalytic performance of both the catalysts with respect to the chosen model reaction of solketal formation using glycerol and acetone is illustrated in the form of Table 3. Here, the ratio of two reactants glycerol:acetone varied from 1:1–1:10 for HBZ and 1:1–1:6 for SZ catalysts respectively. Reactions were carried out for 2 h at 25 °C and 50 °C. And both the employed catalysts were pre-activated for optimum performance as mentioned earlier. The above table shows that for HBZ catalyst, the conversion of glycerol to ketal is lower at 50 °C than that of at 25 °C, and also the selectivity for the 6-membered solketal is higher. While at lower temperatures, 25 °C the catalyst performs well with yields above 80% in all glycerol:acetone ratios. And the selectivity for the 5-membered ring derivative of solketal is near quantitative. However, in the case of SZ, the conversion, and the selectivity for 5-membered ketal both increased at 50 °C compared to the room temperature reaction. This result indicates that HBZ is a more effective catalyst here at milder conditions, however at higher temperatures the SZ equals the HBZ in terms of performance. This result also points toward the fact that in the case of SZ, the removal of H2O requires a higher temperature for effective elimination, whereas the same is facilitated with HBZ at room temperature. Therefore, for reactions involving the removal of water molecules, HBZ could be a more effective catalytic system over the SZ. SZ seems to have higher affinity to bind with water molecules compared to HBZ. However, we assume that this could not only be the reason for the difference in activity between these two catalysts, but rather it could be more related to the number of available acid sites with the capacity to tolerate hydration. This is important as water molecules are released during the reaction, which might bind with catalytic sites and reduce the efficiency of the catalyst. We investigated it by probing the total acidic sites available and differentiating them in Lewis and Brønsted acid sites and their possible role in dehydrative cyclization. 3.2 Role of catalytic sites and their significance Two catalytic systems under investigation, HBZ and SZ possess two different sets of catalytic sites as revealed by NH3-TPD and FTIR analysis of pyridine-adsorbed catalyst samples. SZ has a majority of Brønsted acid sites due to mainly the presence of -SO3H groups and negligible Lewis acid character (emanating from ZrO2), while HBZ would be comprised of both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites due to proton exchanged sites as well as Al2O3 in the zeolite skeleton. Total acidity for both the catalytic systems using temperature programmed was 1.87mMol NH3/g for HBZ and for SZ 1.17 mMol NH3/g. However, the type of acidic sites was measured by pyridine adsorption for 24 h and the bound pyridine on catalytic binding sites was then probed with FT-IR spectroscopy. Fig. 3A and B are basically the FTIR spectrum of pyridine adsorbed HBZ and SZ catalysts respectively. Both these catalysts were pre-heated at various temperatures before being subjected to pyridine adsorption in order to probe the relationship of the number and type of acidic sites with the activation temperatures. Table 4 shows the ratio of Brønsted and Lewis sites based on the area under the peak obtained from the IR spectrum for HBZ pre-activated at various activation temperatures. The ratio of Lewis to Brønsted acid sites is shown in Table 4 as the L/B ratio, which increases with the activation temperature applied for the activation of the catalyst HBZ. This indicates that the effect of temperature on the catalyst produces more Lewis sites with respect to the Brønsted sites. However, our studies with catalyst activation in Table 2 showed that HBZ gives optimum performance in terms of glycerol conversion and selectivity for the 5-membered ring for the candidate with activation temp at 200 °C. Considering this, the L/B ratio for the catalyst which was activated at 200 °C is sufficient to produce the optimum results. In the case of SZ, the activation was imparted at 400 °C as per reported in the literature [21]. Pyridine adsorption studies and subsequent IR analysis revealed that the SZ catalyst does not have a significant amount of Lewis acid sites and the dominant acidic sites in these catalysts were of Brønsted acid nature (as per Fig. 1B). This distinction of active acid sites in both these catalysts was further probed using the reusability of the catalyst. The Brønsted sites in SZ are due to SO3H groups and reported to bind with water molecules in hydronium ion form as conjugate acid-base pairs. This would reduce the availability of active Brønsted sites for catalytic transformation. Higher tolerance of Lewis acid sites towards water molecules ensures that the water molecules generated during the reaction are swept away with the water-friendly reactant such as acetone. And therefore, when the proportion of acetone vis-à-vis glycerol is increased in the reaction mixture, the presence of water on the catalyst surface was found to be decreased. Fig. 4 shows that with 1:2 glycerol to acetone ratio the IR peaks for the presence of H2O and hydroxyl groups are reduced compared to the ratio of 1:1 for glycerol to acetone. This indicates that increasing the amount of acetone with respect to glycerol might help in enhancing the yield. As it is going to remove the water being generated during the reaction more effectively, apart from the conventional role of shifting the equilibrium of the reaction towards products. And therefore at 1:10 glycerol:acetone ratio, the yield of the reaction is near quantitative. 3.3 Reusability of catalysts As per the reported literature, there are numerous papers where acetalization/ketalization of glycerol using a solid acid catalyst is demonstrated and discussed in detail. However, the reusability of the catalyst is the most desired property in establishing the commercial viability of the process. As discussed in a mini review by I. Fatimah et al., the major bottlenecks are the stability of catalysts, the presence of water as impurities in the reactants, and the deactivation of the catalysts [10]. Here, we have compared the reusability of HBZ and SZ with respect to the solketal formation. Considering the site affinity of water towards the Brønsted sites and the availability of a significant amount of Lewis acid sites over the Brønsted sites in HBZ, it can be predicted that the HBZ would have less chances of getting affected by water being released during reaction. And hence, shall be reusable for subsequent cycles with minimal regeneration efforts. To gauge this, we performed reusability studies with both the catalysts at their optimum performing conditions. The catalysts HBZ and SZ were filtered off after each cycle of reaction and were employed directly for the subsequent cycle without any extra workup. Here, HBZ showed excellent performance by maintaining above 80% conversion of glycerol till 10 cycles, while SZ showed a drop of approximately 50% in activity by the 3rd cycle, and at the 7th cycle, the conversion of glycerol was below 20%. Fig. 5 depicts the reusability tests for both the catalysts. The drop in the performance of SZ is attributed to the binding of generated water molecules to Brønsted acidic sites, and thus deactivating them. There is also a possibility of sulfate leaching from the surface of the SZ catalyst. The leaching of sulfate from the catalyst would reflect in the lower sulfur content if tested after multiple cycles of catalytic conversions for solketal reaction on SZ. The CHNS analysis of fresh SZ showed 11.3% of sulfur while the sample tested after 7 cycles showed only 8.2% of sulfur. This showed the leaching of SZ in terms of loss of -SO4 2- sites. Therefore, the drop in conversion performance of SZ is due to site deactivation followed by leaching of Sulfur rendering the catalyst less efficient after each cycle. While on the other hand, HBZ has dominating Lewis acid sites which are least affected by the presence of water in the reaction mixture after each cycle of solketal formation. And since the Lewis acid sites do not have an affinity towards water molecules, water molecules do not adhere to the Lewis acid sites and get swept away with the acetone available in the reaction mixture. The availability of adequate Lewis acid sites on HBZ not only makes it more facile in the conversion of glycerol but it also exhibits excellent reusability for multiple cycles of reaction without washing or activation, whatsoever. This trait of water tolerance and hence superior reusability for Lewis acid dominant systems was also reported by several researchers e.g., M. J. da Silva et al. has a series of publications indicating similar findings like ours [7,8]. On the other hand, SZ suffers due to the deactivation of acid sites by released water in the first cycle of reaction. This hampered the conversion percentage of glycerol in the second cycle, and this continued with each subsequent cycle finally the conversion dropping to very low values. So, the formation of water in the course of the reaction does affect the catalyst performance in the case of SZ but not significantly for HBZ, where up to 10 cycles the glycerol conversion remained ∼80%. In both cases the proportion of acetone to glycerol was 2:1. However at 1:1 acetone:glycerol ratio too, HBZ performed better at milder conditions compared to SZ. This finding is in affirmation with the previously reported candidates employed for continuous flow process, which includes sulfonated solid acids supported on resins, silica, mixed oxides, carbon, montmorillonite, and zeolites [7,10,22–24] for a continuous flow reaction process. We also studied the FTIR of the spent catalyst after the first cycle in the case of HBZ for glycerol/acetone 1:1 and 1:2 ratio and it was found that the water generated in the 1:1 composition reaction, was adhering more to the spent catalyst surface compared to that of the 1:2 composition reaction as can be seen in Fig. 4(b) and (c), where the excess of adhering water in 1:1 glycerol/acetone composition can be seen as more intense and broader peak in FTIR curve (b) compared to that of curve (c). This proves that the excess of acetone acts as a solvent and removes H2O from the catalyst and delays its poisoning. And therefore, in literature, the high acetone:glycerol ratios [22] have shown near quantitative yields for the reaction. In our case too, 10:1 acetone:glycerol ratio with a 5% HBZ catalyst gave the conversion and selectivity for a 5-membered solketal of 98% (Table 3). FTIR spectra for pyridine-adsorbed spent HBZ indicates an expected reduction in L/B ratio and in the case of SZ the diminishing peak at 1535 cm−1 for the Brønsted site was observed [Supplementary Material Figs. S1 and S2]. Also, the data of conversion and selectivity of 5 & 6-membered ring isomers for both the catalytic system are tabulated and provided as supplementary material Table S1. To prove our rationale of HBZ’s Lewis acid sites are more tolerant towards the water, we have performed an experiment where a mole-equivalent of water was added in prior to the glycerol-acetone mixture, and a reaction was performed with a 5% catalyst, which showed 71% conversion of glycerol with 98% selectivity for ketal (Table 3). 3.4 Plausible mechanism for solketal formation over HBZ and SZ The plausible mechanism of dehydrative ketalization of glycerol with acetone to solketal is depicted in Scheme 2. The acetone can be activated by Brønsted and Lewis acid sites (of SZ and HBZ, respectively) for nucleophilic addition reaction of glycerol as reported by M. J. da Silva et al [7,8]. The resulting addition product (Hemi-Ketal; HK) remains adsorbed on acidic sites (Brønsted/ Lewis) and undergoes cyclization through nucleophilic attack of secondary –OH producing (2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxolan-4-yl)methanol, that is solketal. While the cyclization of HK through nucleophilic attack of primary (terminal) –OH will form 2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxan-5-ol (6-membered dioxane derivative). The FT-IR spectra of spent SZ [ Fig. 6(B)(b)] showed the presence of ionic bidentate chelating sulfate species showing bands in the range of 1242–998 cm−1, which are responsible for Brønsted acidic sites. The band at 1450 cm−1 in the spent SZ is corresponding to C-H bending of adsorbed organic species (reactants and/or products). The increased broadness of -OH stretching band in spent SZ represents adsorbed water molecules (produced during the reaction) on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, the significant increased weight loss in the first derivative of TGA curves, i.e., DTG of spent SZ ( Fig. 7 B) also indicates the adsorbed organic species and water molecules. The co-product water molecules adsorbed on Brønsted acidic sites of SZ (hydrated Brønsted sites; Scheme 2) may lower down the strength of sites. The S content in SZ, measured by CHNS analysis, was 11.3%, which got reduced to 8.2% in the spent SZ. This is indicative of the interaction of water molecules with surface SO4 2- leaching out SO4 2- ions. These are responsible for the Brønsted acidic sites, hence reducing the Brønsted acidity upon their loss. The FT-IR, thermal analysis, and S content measurements clearly show the deactivation of SZ is due to the adsorption of organic species and binding of water molecules on Brønsted acid sites and subsequent leaching of SO4 2- ions, reducing their efficiency in the next reaction cycles. On the other hand, no significant change in the FT-IR spectrum (Fig. 6A-b) and DTG of spent HBZ (Fig. 7A) compared to the fresh HBZ, indicates a good stability of HBZ in the reaction. The water molecules adsorbed on Lewis acidic sites of HBZ (Scheme 2) may act as Brønsted acidic sites [25], which can catalyze the reaction the same way as discussed for SZ. However, in FT-IR of pyridine adsorbed spent HΒΖ, we could not detect the Brønsted acidic sites produced by hydration of Lewis acidic sites, which may be because of the removal of adsorbed water molecules from Lewis sites while drying of spent catalyst (before performing pyridine adsorption). 4 Conclusions Here we have tried to generate the fundamental knowledge about the contemplated catalytic systems’ performances by probing the role of the typical acidic sites in a water-producing reaction. In this attempt, we remained focused on the industrial applicability and scalability of the process, and therefore we exercised the reusability up to 10 cycles without any post-reaction treatment to the heterogeneous catalyst. The catalyst HBZ was found to have a higher surface area, and higher acidic sites, moreover, it consisted significantly high amount of Lewis acid sites which were found not to be affected by water molecules produced during the reaction and remained active. This system has such a good tolerance towards water that it works with 1 equivalent of water molecules pre-added to the reactants and still gave about 70% conversion at 1:2 proportion of glycerol to acetone. Our solvent-free reaction procedure with a 1:2 glycerol/acetone ratio is optimized to give 82% conversion with excellent selectivity towards a 5-membered dioxolane candidate, solketal. coredata.dc:description: The glycerol value addition by ketalization with acetone leads to solketal. Herein, we demonstrate the comparative efficiency of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, using Hβ-zeolite & sulfated zirconia (SO4 2--ZrO2) as Brønsted and Lewis acid catalysts, respectively, for ketalization of glycerol to solketal. The catalysts were characterized using conventional techniques. Total acidity of both catalysts was ascertained with NH3-TPD. The sulfur content of SO4 2--ZrO2 was determined by CHNS analysis. The Brønsted/Lewis character of total acid sites for both catalysts was determined using FTIR of pyridine-Chemisorbed catalysts. Studies revealed that 5% (w/w) catalyst, 25 °C temperature and 2-hour reaction time were optimum parameters for Hβ-zeolite while, SO4 2--ZrO2 required 50 °C to match the performance. Hβ-zeolite exhibited higher selectivity at lower temperatures towards ketal and reusability without any performance drop upto 10 cycles. The performance-edge vis-à-vis reusability of catalysts indicated tolerance of Lewis acid sites towards hydration, where Hβ-zeolite outperforms SO4 2--ZrO2.
coredata.dc:title: Investigation on site-specific tolerance to water for solid acid catalysts employed for a model reaction of solketal formation
